ruleGroup.title: Schema Component Constraint: Complex Type Definition Properties Correct
ruleGroup.rule: The values of the properties of a complex type definition must be as described in the property tableau in The Complex Type Definition Schema Component (§3.4.1), modulo the impact of Missing Sub-components (§5.3).
If the {base type definition} is a simple type definition, the {derivation method} must be extension.
Circular definitions are disallowed, except for the ·ur-type definition·. That is, it must be possible to reach the ·ur-type definition· by repeatedly following the {base type definition}.
Two distinct attribute declarations in the {attribute uses} must not have identical {name}s and {target namespace}s.
Two distinct attribute declarations in the {attribute uses} must not have {type definition}s which are or are derived from ID.

ruleGroup.title: Schema Representation Constraint: Complex Type Definition Representation OK
ruleGroup.rule: If the <simpleContent> alternative is chosen, the <complexType> element must not have mixed = true.
If <openContent> is present and has mode ≠ 'none', then there must be an <any> among the [children] of <openContent>
If <openContent> is present and has mode = 'none', then there must not be an <any> among the [children] of <openContent>
If the <complexContent> alternative is chosen and the mixed [attribute] is present on both <complexType> and <complexContent> then ·actual values· of those [attributes] must be the same.

ruleGroup.title: Schema Representation Constraint: Simple Type Definition Representation OK
ruleGroup.rule: With the exception of <enumeration>, <pattern>, and <assert>, the [children] of <restriction> do not contain more than one element information item with the same name.
If the <restriction> alternative is chosen, it has either a base [attribute] or a <simpleType> among its [children], but not both.
If the <list> alternative is chosen, it has either an itemType [attribute] or a <simpleType> among its [children], but not both.
If the <union> alternative is chosen, either it has a non-empty memberTypes [attribute] or it has at least one simpleType [child].

ruleGroup.title: Schema Component Constraint: Simple Type Definition Properties Correct
ruleGroup.rule: The {final} of the {base type definition} does not contain restriction.

ruleGroup.title: Schema Representation Constraint: Attribute Declaration Representation OK
ruleGroup.rule: default and fixed must not both be present.
If default and use are both present, use must have the ·actual value· optional.
If the item's parent is not <schema>, then all of the following must be true: 1 One of ref or name is present, but not both. 2 If ref is present, then all of <simpleType>, form and type are absent.
The type attribute and a <simpleType> child element must not both be present.
If fixed and use are both present, use must not have the ·actual value· prohibited.

If the targetNamespace attribute is present then all of the following must be true: 1 The name attribute is present. 2 The form attribute is absent. 3 If the ancestor <schema> does not have a targetNamespace [attribute] or its ·actual value· is different from the ·actual value· of targetNamespace of <attribute>, then all of the following are true: 3.1 <attribute> has <complexType> as an ancestor 3.2 There is a <restriction> ancestor between the <attribute> and the nearest <complexType> ancestor, and the ·actual value· of the base [attribute] of <restriction> does not ·match· the name of ·xs:anyType·.

ruleGroup.title: Schema Representation Constraint: Element Declaration Representation OK
ruleGroup.rule: default and fixed are not both present.

If the item's parent is not <schema> then all of the following are true: 1 One of ref or name is present, but not both. 2 If ref is present, then all of <complexType> <simpleType> <key> <keyref> <unique> nillable, default, fixed, form, block and type are absent, i.e. only minOccurs, maxOccurs, id and <annotation> are allowed to appear together with ref.
The <element> element does not have both a <simpleType> or <complexType> child and a type attribute.

If targetNamespace is present then all of the following are true: 1 name is present. 2 form is not present. 3 If the ancestor <schema> does not have a targetNamespace [attribute] or its ·actual value· is different from the ·actual value· of targetNamespace of <element>, then all of the following are true: 3.1 <element> has <complexType> as an ancestor 3.2 There is a <restriction> ancestor between the <element> and the nearest <complexType> ancestor, and the ·actual value· of the base [attribute] of <restriction> does not ·match· the name of ·xs:anyType·.
Every <alternative> element but the last has a test [attribute]; the last <alternative> element may have such an [attribute].

ruleGroup.title: Schema Representation Constraint: Element Declaration Representation OK - Unmapped
ruleGroup.rule: The allowed values for abstract attribute on Element Declaration, are {true, false}
The allowed values for nillable attribute on Element Declaration, are {true, false}
The allowed values for final attribute on Element Declaration, are {restriction, extension, #all}
The allowed values for block attribute on Element Declaration, are {restriction, extension, substitution, #all}
The allowed values for form attribute on Element Declaration, are {qualified, unqualified}

ruleGroup.title: Schema Component Constraint: ComplexTypeDefinition Derivation Valid (Extension)
ruleGroup.rule: For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = extension 1) If B is a complex type definition, then all of the following are true: 1.1) B.{final} does not contain extension.

For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = extension 1) If B is a complex type definition, then all of the following are true: 1.2) B.{attribute uses} is a subset of T.{attribute uses}. That is, for every attribute use U in B.{attribute uses}, there is an attribute use in T.{attribute uses} whose properties, recursively, are identical to those of U.

For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = extension 1) If B is a complex type definition, then all of the following are true: 1.3) If B has an {attribute wildcard}, then T also has one, and B.{attribute wildcard}.{namespace constraint} is a subset of T.{attribute wildcard}.{namespace constraint}, as defined by Wildcard Subset (§3.10.6.2).

For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = extension 1) If B is a complex type definition, then all of the following are true: 1.4) One of the following is true: 1.4.1) B and T both have {content type}.{variety} = simple and both have the same {content type}.{simple type definition}. 1.4.2) B and T both have {content type}.{variety} = empty. 1.4.3) All of the following are true: ... ......

For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = extension
2) If B is a simple type definition, then all of the following are true: 2.1) T.{content type}.{variety} = simple and T.{content type}.{simple type definition} = B. 2.2) B.{final} does not contain extension.
(refer to complete set of rules at http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema11-1/#sec-cos-ct-extends)

ruleGroup.title: Schema Component Constraint: ComplexTypeDefinition Derivation Valid (Restriction)
ruleGroup.rule: For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = restriction, all of the following must be true: 1) B is a complex type definition whose {final} does not contain restriction. 2) One or more of the following is true: ... .... (refer to complete set of rules at http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema11-1/#sec-derivation-ok-restriction)

For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = restriction, all of the following must be true: 1) B is a complex type definition whose {final} does not contain restriction.

For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = restriction, all of the following must be true: 2) One or more of the following is true: 2.1) B is ·xs:anyType·. 2.2) All of the following are true: 2.2.1) T.{content type}.{variety} = simple ... .... (refer to complete set of rules at http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema11-1/#sec-derivation-ok-restriction)

For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = restriction, all of the following must be true: 3) For every element information item E, if the [attributes] of E satisfy clause 2 and clause 3 of Element Locally Valid (Complex Type) (§3.4.4.2) with respect to T, then they also satisfy the same clauses with respect to B, and for every attribute information item A in E.[attributes], B's ·default binding· for A ·subsumes· that defined by T.

For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = restriction, all of the following must be true: 4) For any element or attribute information item, its ·locally declared type· within T is ·validly substitutable· for its ·locally declared type· within B, subject to the blocking keywords {extension, list, union}, if the item has a ·locally declared type· both in T and in B.
For every complex type T with {base type definition} B where T.{derivation method} = restriction, all of the following must be true: 5) B.{assertions} is a prefix of T.{assertions}.

ruleGroup.title: Schema Component Constraint: Derivation Valid (Restriction, Simple)
ruleGroup.rule: For any Simple Type Definition D whose {base type definition} is some Simple Type Definition B, following rule applies: Either D is ·xs:anyAtomicType·, or else B is an atomic simple type definition.
For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being atomic) whose {base type definition} is some Simple Type Definition B, following rule applies: B.{final} does not contain restriction.

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being atomic) whose {base type definition} is some Simple Type Definition B, following rule applies: For each facet in D.{facets} (call this DF) all of the following are true: 1. DF is applicable to D, as specified in Applicable Facets of [XML Schema: Datatypes]. 2. DF satisfies the constraints on facet components given in the appropriate subsection of Constraining Facets in [XML Schema: Datatypes].

For a Simple Type Definition D(variety being list) which is constructed by specifying an item type, following rule applies: Either D.{item type definition}.{variety} = atomic or D.{item type definition}.{variety} = union and there are no types whose {variety} is list among the union's transitive membership.

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being list) which is derived by restriction, from another Simple Type Definition B, such that B is ·xs:anySimpleType·, following rule applies: D.{item type definition}.{final} does not contain list.

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being list) which is derived by restriction, from another Simple Type Definition B, such that B is ·xs:anySimpleType·, following rule applies: D.{facets} contains only the whiteSpace facet component with {value} = collapse and {fixed} = true.
For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being list) which is derived by restriction, from another Simple Type Definition B(variety being list), following rule applies: B.{variety} = list

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being list) which is derived by restriction, from another Simple Type Definition B(variety being list), following rule applies: B.{final} does not contain restriction.

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being list) which is derived by restriction, from another Simple Type Definition B(variety being list), following rule applies: D.{item type definition} is validly ·derived· from B.{item type definition}, as defined in Type Derivation OK (Simple) (§3.16.6.3).

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being list) which is derived by restriction, from another Simple Type Definition B(variety being list), following rule applies: All facets in {facets} are applicable to D, as specified in Applicable Facets.

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being list) which is derived by restriction, from another Simple Type Definition B(variety being list), following rule applies: All facets in {facets} satisfy the constraints on facet components given in the appropriate subsection of Constraining Facets.

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being union) constructed by specifying one or more member types, whose {base type definition} being a Simple Type Definition B(which is a ·xs:anySimpleType), following rule applies: All of the {member type definitions} have a {final} which does not contain union.

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being union) constructed by specifying one or more member types, whose {base type definition} being a Simple Type Definition B(which is a ·xs:anySimpleType), following rule applies: D.{facets} is empty.
For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being union) ·derived· by restriction from another Simple Type Definition B(variety being union), following rule applies: B.{variety} = union.

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being union) ·derived· by restriction from another Simple Type Definition B(variety being union), following rule applies: B.{final} does not contain restriction.

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being union) ·derived· by restriction from another Simple Type Definition B(variety being union), following rule applies: Each type definition in D.{member type definitions} is validly ·derived· from the corresponding type definition in B.{member type definitions}, as defined in Type Derivation OK (Simple) (§3.16.6.3).

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being union) ·derived· by restriction from another Simple Type Definition B(variety being union), following rule applies: All facets in {facets} are applicable to D, as specified in Applicable Facets.

For any Simple Type Definition D(variety being union) ·derived· by restriction from another Simple Type Definition B(variety being union), following rule applies: All facets in {facets} satisfy the constraints on facet components given in the appropriate subsection of Constraining Facets.
Neither D nor any type ·derived· from it is a member of its own transitive membership.
